poem:
Title: "A Silent Silver Reel"

Bedlam of Cannes, a festival feast,
Labour's intentions poised to release.
British creators, marooned for shows,
Eurimage's absence, a wound only grows.

Council's silver screen in distant France,
Invites us again to join the dance.
For culture's seed needs fertile land,
Let's seize the olive branch in hand.

In potholes, dreams lie, tipped and terse,
Threads of a story, Britain's re-etched verse.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A Cannes-do attitude to Europe’s film fund | Brief letters Perhaps the first week of the Cannes film festival would be a good time for Labour to announce its intention to rejoin Eurimages, the Council of Europe’s film and television funding institution. The UK’s withdrawal from this and other European cultural institutions has served no purpose other than to place British creators at a disadvantage compared with their European counterparts.Bernard BesserglikPantin, France • Potholes, fly-tipping". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
